State Key Laboratory of Clean and Efficient Coal Utilization, College of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Taiyuan University of Technology Taiyuan Shanxi 030024 PR China The selective catalytic oxidation of ammonia (NH3-SCO) is currently the most effective method used to eliminate NH3. However, one of the major challenges for NH3-SCO is the development of catalyst capable of completely converting NH3 into harmless N2 and water vapor. In this paper, a high N2 selective catalyst prepared by the sol-gel method using TiO2 as the support, Cu as the active species, and Sm as the auxiliary agent is presented. Compared to traditional Cu/TiO2 catalyst, the 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst has higher catalytic activity and N2 selectivity at low temperatures. The NH3 conversion can reach 100%, and the selectivity of N2 can be maintained at 100% at 275 °C. The excellent catalytic activity is attributed to the highly dispersed active species, abundant Lewis acid sites (LASs), and the generation of large amounts of surface-adsorbed oxygen. In addition, doping Sm species will cause TiO2 lattice distortion, and at the same time load the distorted TiO2 with more active material. Moreover, in-situ DRIFTS analysis suggests that both the 4SmCu/TiO2 and Cu/TiO2 catalysts follow the "internal" selective catalytic reduction (iSCR) mechanism during NH3-SCO reactions. The 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst generates more amides (-NH2), which reduces the non-selective oxidation of the catalysts and promotes the formation of N2. This provides a new idea and method for the selective catalytic oxidation of NH3 to N2 and water vapor using Cu-based catalysts. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords NH3-SCO N2 selective Mechanism In-situ DRIFTs Copper catalysis Data availability The authors are unable or have chosen not to specify which data has been used. 1 Introduction At present, due to the strict NOx emission standards, excessive NH3 has been utilized in the NH3-SCR reaction, leading to the release of unreacted NH3 into the atmosphere and resulting in ammonia escape [1,2]. Higher levels of NH3 in the environment can have detrimental effects on human health and the ecosystem. Numerous studies have demonstrated that elevated concentrations of NH3 in the environment can cause respiratory issues, contribute to acid rain, and lead to eutrophication in aquatic ecosystems [3,4]. It is crucial to urgently address the removal of leaked ammonia from the atmosphere to safeguard both our health and the environment [5,6]. Therefore, the development of effective methods to eliminate NH3 from the atmosphere is essential. A variety of methods have been investigated to address the issue of ammonia gas, including biological methods [7], adsorption methods [8], catalytic combustion methods [9,10], and catalytic oxidation method [5,11]. Among these, NH3 selective catalytic oxidation (NH3-SCO) technology has gained significant attention due to its advantages such as lower operating costs, minimal secondary pollution, and lower energy consumption [12]. The NH3-SCO reaction is shown in Eq. (1), which is the primary reaction for NH3-SCO. However, side reactions (Eqs. (2)–(4)) frequently occur simultaneously with the primary reaction, leading to the production of harmful NOx. Therefore, the main challenge for NH3-SCO catalysts is to prevent the occurrence of side reactions [13]. (1) 4 NH 3 + 3 O 2 → 2 N 2 + 6 H 2 O (2) 2 NH 3 + 2 O 2 → N 2 O + 3 H 2 O (3) 4 NH 3 + 5 O 2 → 4 NO + 6 H 2 O (4) 4 NH 3 + 7 O 2 → 4 NO 2 + 6 H 2 O In the NH3-SCO reaction, three main types of catalysts are used: noble metal catalysts [14,15], modified zeolite-based catalysts [16,17], transition metal oxide catalysts [18,19]. Noble metal catalysts, also known as ammonia escape catalysts (ASC), are commonly placed after the NH3-SCR unit and are widely utilized for their high NH3 conversion at low temperatures [20–22]. However, the insufficient thermal stability of noble metal catalysts leads to the production of NOx by-products alongside N2, and their high cost limits their practical applications [23]. Modified zeolite-based catalysts containing precious or transition metals have also been used widely, but they still have some shortcomings [24,25]. Wang et al. developed a catalyst containing silver particles (Ag/ZSM-5-OH) encapsulated by hollow ZSM-5, which had certain cyclic stability but sacrificed NH3 conversion [26]. Transition metal oxide catalysts have garnered attention due to their high thermal stability, excellent N2 selectivity, and lower cost. Recent research has focused on Cu-based catalysts due to their mild redox properties and high catalytic activity in medium temperatures [20]. Il'Chenko's study indicated that CuO is the active ingredient in the NH3-SCO reaction, but N2 selectivity did not reach the expected level [27]. Trombetta et al. proposed a mixed metal oxide derived from CuMgAl hydrotalcite, achieving 100% NH3 conversion at 400–500 ℃, although N2 selectivity was below 80% [28]. Therefore, there is an urgent need to develop a catalyst that can ensure both high N2 selectivity and NH3 conversion. In recent years, the addition of auxiliary agents has been found to help overcome the limitations of single active species, thereby enhancing the catalytic activity of the catalyst. Different types of auxiliary agents can impact the dispersion, specific surface area, pore structure, and acid site content of the catalyst [29–31]. For example, Li et al. reported that Cu or Pt substituted B-site in perovskite and improved the redox capacity of the catalyst, which enhanced its catalytic activity [32]. Ma et al. showed that doping W in a Cu0.02Fe0.2TiOx catalyst increased the content of acid sites and improved its catalytic performance in NH3-SCR reaction [33]. The rare earth element Sm is often employed as an additive in the NH3-SCR reaction. Chen et al. reported on the Sm-modified Mn/BC catalyst. Doping of Sm species increased the content of weak and medium acids in the catalyst, thus increasing the active site of SCR reaction [34]. Qin et al. designed an Sm-modified MnTiSnOy composite oxide to improve the durability of H2O and SO2 in NH3-SCR processes [35]. A series of studies have shown that the catalyst modified by Sm species exhibits excellent catalytic activity in the NH3-SCR reaction, but the effect of Sm on the active substance in the NH3-SCO process has been less reported. In this paper, a high-performance Cu/TiO2 catalyst was modified with rare earth element Sm using the sol-gel method. Various characterization techniques, such as BET, XRD, Raman, H2-TPR, TEM, SEM, XPS, O2-TPD, Pyridine infrared, NH3-TPD and in-situ DRIFTs, were employed to examine the physical structure, chemically active species, redox characteristics, acidic nature, and reaction mechanism of the catalyst. The results revealed that the addition of Sm not only enhanced NH3 conversion but also had a significant influence on improving N2 selectivity. A noteworthy finding was that the 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst did not produce any byproducts during the reaction within the temperature range of 150–275 °C. This promising outcome suggests a novel approach for preventing the escape of NH3 during the NH3-SCO reaction. Overall, these findings demonstrate the potential of utilizing Sm doping to enhance the performance and selectivity of Cu/TiO2 catalyst, as well as providing insights into the elimination of NH3 leakage during the reaction. 2 Experiment section 2.1 Catalysts preparation The Sm-doped Cu/TiO2 catalysts were synthesized using the sol-gel method, as described in the literature. Specifically, Prepare a mixture of n-butanol (25.2 mL) and glacial acetic acid (2.8 mL), add a certain amount of Sm (NO3)3 6 H2O and 0.68 g of Cu(NO3)2 3 H2O, stir for 30 min. Then, tetrabutyl titanate (9.6 mL) was added and the mixture was stirred for an additional hour. The resulting mixture was dried at 105 ℃ for 24 h and calcined at 500 ℃ for 4 h in a Muffle oven. The prepared catalysts were labeled as xSmCu/TiO2, where x represents the molar ratio of Sm (NO3)3 6 H2O to Cu(NO3)2. For example, 4SmCu/TiO2 indicates a molar ratio of 4:10 of Sm (NO3)3 6 H2O to Cu(NO3)2 3 H2O. 2.2 Catalysts characterization The structural and physical characteristics of the catalysts were investigated using a range of characterizations, including BET, XRD, Raman, H2-TPR, TEM, SEM, and XPS. The chemical characteristics of the catalysts were studied using H2-TPR, O2-TPD, Pyridine infrared NH3-TPD and in-situ DRIFTs. The detailed experimental procedures and specific operation methods can be found in the supporting information. 2.3 Catalysts activity testing and kinetic measurement The performance of the catalysts was evaluated using a fixed-bed reactor. The reactor consisted of three main components: a gas distribution system, a reaction system and a detection system. The feed gas contains 500 ppm NH3 and 5 vol% O2 in He (equilibrium gas). The total flow rate was 100 mL min−1, the catalyst mass was 500 mg (40–60 mesh), and the space velocity (GHSV was 60,000⋅h−1). Infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) spectrometer (KR 50) was used for continuous detection of inlet and outlet gas components, including NH3, N2O, NO, and NO2. The NH3 conversion, N2 selectivity, N2 yield, NOx selectivity and N2O selectivity were calculated using the following equations. (5) NH 3 Conversion % = NH 3 in − NH 3 out NH 3 in × 100 % (6) N 2 Selectivity % = [ NH 3 ] in − NH 3 out − 2 [ N 2 O ] out − NO out − [ NO 2 ] out [ NH 3 ] in − NH 3 out × 100 % (7) N 2 Yield % = NH 3 Conversion × N 2 Selectivity × 100 % (8) N 2 O Selectivity % = [ N 2 O ] out [ NH 3 ] in − NH 3 out × 100 % (9) NO Selectivity % = NO out [ NH 3 ] in − NH 3 out × 100 % (10) NO 2 Selectivity % = [ NO 2 ] out [ NH 3 ] in − NH 3 out × 100 % where, [NH3]in represents the inlet concentration of NH3; [NH3]out, [N2O]out, [NO]out and [NO2]out represent the outlet concentrations of NH3, N2O, NO and NO2, respectively. Kinetic measurements were also conducted in fixed-bed reactors with gas compositions of 250 ppm, 500 ppm, and 750 ppm NH3, 5% O2, and He as the equilibrium gas. The space velocity was controlled at 60,000⋅h−1 by adjusting the amount of catalyst (where 250 mg corresponds to 250 ppm NH3, 500 mg corresponds to 500 ppm NH3, and 750 mg corresponds to 750 ppm NH3). The corresponding total flow rates were set at 50 mL min−1, 100 mL min−1, and 150 mL min−1. To maintain the NH3 conversion rate below 20%, kinetic measurements were conducted at temperatures ranging from 120 °C to 160 °C. For detailed equations and steps on calculating the apparent activation energy, please refer to the supporting information. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effect of Sm incorporation on catalytic activity The NH3 conversion, N2 selectivity, N2 yield, N2O selectivity NO selectivity and NO2 selectivity were evaluated for the selective catalytic oxidation of ammonia. As shown in Fig. 1(a), the 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst exhibited the highest catalytic activity. It achieved NH3 conversion of 30% at 200 °C, which increased to 100% at 275 °C. In comparison, the Cu/TiO2 catalyst also reached 100% conversion but required a higher temperature of 300 °C. This indicates that the addition of Sm species enhances the catalytic performance of NH3-SCO. However, excessive doping of Sm substances may actually have a negative effect on catalytic activity, as evidenced by the significantly lower catalytic activity of the 10SmCu/TiO2 catalyst compared to the Cu/TiO2 catalyst. This may be due to the competition between excess Sm species and active Cu species for binding sites on the TiO2 support, which could lead to reduced active material on the support and ultimately lower catalytic activity. It can be seen from Fig. 1(b) that the N2 selectivity of Cu/TiO2 catalyst is close to 100% between 150 and 225 ℃, but with the increase of temperature, the N2 selectivity of Cu/TiO2 catalyst begins to decline at 225 ℃, and the conversion of NH3 reaches 100% when the temperature rises to 300 ℃. N2 selectivity decreased to 54%, indicating that a large number of by-products were produced. However, the N2 selectivity of 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst remained at 100% during the whole temperature window from 150 ℃ to 275 ℃. It can be seen from Fig. 1(a) that the conversion of NH3 reaches 100% at 275 ℃, indicating that the 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst converts all NH3 into harmless N2 and water vapor during the reaction. Fig. 1(c) shows the N2 yield for the different catalysts. By comparing Fig. 1(c) and (a), it can be observed that the N2 yield curve and NH3 conversion curve of the 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst coincide completely at 150–275 °C. This confirms that N2 selectivity remains 100% in the temperature range, indicating that the 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst has good catalytic activity when participating in the reaction in the temperature range of 150–275 °C. Fig. 1(d) shows the N2O selectivity spectrum, and it can be observed that the Cu/TiO2 catalyst begins to appear byproducts at 225 °C and a large number of N2O byproducts at 300 °C. However, when the 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst reaches 300 °C, the N2O content only reaches 5%. Fig. 1(e) shows the NO selectivity spectrum, and it can be seen that at 250 °C, the Cu/TiO2 catalyst begins to show NO and reaches 6% NO content at 300 °C. The 2SmCu/TiO2 catalyst began to show NO at 275 °C and also reached 6% at 300 °C. Other catalysts did not observe NO throughout the temperature window. Based on the analysis results of Fig. 9, it can be concluded that the introduction of Sm substance can convert the generated NO into harmless N2 and water vapor, thereby suppressing the generation of side reactions. This is why xSmCu/TiO2 catalysts have good N2 selectivity. Fig. 1(f) shows the NO2 selectivity spectrum, and it can be seen that no NO2 production was observed over the entire temperature window, indicating that the two catalysts did not produce NO2. In this paper, the catalytic performance of Cu/TiO2 catalyst, 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst, 4Sm/TiO2 catalyst and TiO2 catalyst was evaluated and analyzed, as shown in Fig. S1(a). It can be observed that the NH3 conversion remained below 10% throughout the temperature range for both the 4Sm/TiO2 catalyst and TiO2 catalyst without Cu species doping. This suggests that the introduction of Sm species is only used as an auxiliary agent to improve the structure and properties of Cu species. Moreover, the stability of the catalyst was evaluated. As shown in Fig. S2, the stability of the catalysts was assessed at 275 °C, which corresponds to the temperature with the highest NH3 conversion. The 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst exhibited excellent stability, maintaining a conversion of 100%, along with N2 selectivity exceeding 99%. These results indicate that the catalyst remained stable during the NH3-SCO reaction, without significant degradation or loss of performance. The cycle stability of the catalyst is an important indicator for evaluating its performance. In this paper, the cycle stability of the Cu/TiO2 catalyst and the 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst was tested. Fig. S3 shows the results of the catalysts under the same reaction conditions for 5 repeated experiments. As seen in the figure, both catalysts maintain the same NH3 conversion at the same temperature point. Additionally, the N2 selectivity remains unchanged after 5 cycles. This indicates that both catalysts exhibit good cycle stability. 3.2 Catalysts surface characteristics 3.2.1 Textural characterization of catalysts As shown in Fig. 2, the adsorption-desorption isotherms of both the Cu/TiO2 catalyst and the xSmCu/TiO2 catalysts exhibit a typical type IV shape, indicating harmonic multilayer adsorption on the catalyst surface [36]. The hysteresis ring observed in the isotherms corresponds to an H2-type hysteresis loop, which is characteristic of mesoporous materials with a spherical or ink bottle pore structure. This suggests the presence of intergranular mesopores in the catalysts [37]. Meanwhile, according to the BJH curve, the pore size of xSmCu/TiO2 catalysts ranges from 2.9 to 4 nm and 4–8 nm, while the pore size of Cu/TiO2 catalyst ranges from 3.2 to 4 nm and 4–7 nm. A summary of the specific surface area, pore size, and pore volume of the prepared catalysts is presented in Table 1. It is evident that the xSmCu/TiO2 catalysts exhibits an increased specific surface area compared to the Cu/TiO2 catalyst. The results indicated that the doping of Sm species led to an increase in the specific surface area of the catalysts. This increase in specific surface area was correlated with the enhancement of pore volume, allowing for the exposure of additional active sites. Consequently, this facilitated the adsorption and dissociation of NH3 species [38]. It can be seen Table 1 that at the same temperature, the specific reaction rate of 4SmCu/TiO2 was significantly higher than that of Cu/TiO2, which indicated that the introduction of Sm substance can enhance the activity of catalyst and promote the selective catalytic oxidation reaction of NH3. Meanwhile, the average pore diameter tends to decrease, which may be attributed to the doping of Sm species having an effect on the lattice of TiO2. This hypothesis is supported by XRD and Raman characterization. 3.2.2 Evidence of an increase in active species Fig. 3(a) shows the XRD patterns of Cu/TiO2 catalyst and xSmCu/TiO2 catalysts. It can be observed that no diffraction peaks corresponding to Sm and Cu species are detected, indicating that they exist in a highly dispersed state on the TiO2 support. The redox performance of the catalyst is positively correlated with the presence of highly dispersed CuO species and negatively correlated with cluster CuO species. This suggests that the prepared catalysts exhibits high catalytic activity[39]. Upon doping with Sm and Cu species, the intensity of the diffraction peaks from Cu-doped TiO2 decreases, and the half-peak width increases as the amount of Sm doping increases. The average grain size of the prepared catalyst was estimated by the diffraction peak (101). The Scherrer formula is used to calculate the grain size of TiO2. The results in Table 1 show that the grain size of TiO2 gradually decreases with the doping of Sm species. This indicates that the doping of Sm has a certain effect on the TiO2 support. As can be seen from Fig. S4, with the addition of Sm species, the diffraction peak at 2θ = 25.3° has a higher angular shift, indicating that the introduction of Sm species may change the lattice structure of TiO2 support. These XRD observations demonstrate the interaction between Sm species and TiO2 support, as well as the effect of doping on TiO2 crystal structure and grain size. Fig. 3(b) shows the Raman analysis of the Cu/TiO2 catalyst and xSmCu/TiO2 catalysts. The observed peaks at 143 cm−1, 395 cm−1, 515 cm−1, and 638 cm−1 correspond to the stretching vibrations of the Eg, B1 g, A1 g, and Eg modes of the TiO2 anatase structure, respectively[40]. The Eg peak corresponds to the symmetric stretching vibration of O-Ti-O, the B1 g peak corresponds to the symmetric bending vibration of O-Ti-O, and the A1 g peak corresponds to the antisymmetric bending vibration caused by O-Ti-O. Previous literature reports that the O-Ti-O symmetric stretching vibration below 300 cm−1 is attributed to lattice vibrations[41]. It can be observed from Fig. S5 that the Eg Raman peak at 143 cm−1 is blue shifted with the doping of Sm species. These results indicate that doping of Sm species can affect the symmetric stretching vibration of O-Ti-O and cause blue shift of Eg Raman peak. Combined with XRD analysis, it was shown that doping Sm substances would lead to lattice distortion of TiO2. However, no peaks of crystalline titanite and rutile TiO2 are observed in the change of peaks, and anatase TiO2 phase is still maintained. Furthermore, the absence of Raman peaks from Sm and Cu in the figure confirms that Sm and Cu species are highly dispersed on the TiO2 support, which is consistent with the XRD results, supporting the catalytic activity observed in previous analyses. Fig. 3(c) shows the H2-TPR spectra of Cu/TiO2 catalyst and xSmCu/TiO2 catalysts. H2-TPR can effectively detect the reducibility of Cu/TiO2 catalyst and xSmCu/TiO2 catalysts, as well as the dispersion of active species on the support. As shown in Fig. 3(c), the α peak can be attributed to the reduction of CuO species with a high dispersion on the catalyst surface, and the β peak is the reduction peak of Cu2+ → Cu+ transition. The γ peak is a reducing peak of Cu+ → Cu0 transformation[42]. The position of α and β peaks of xSmCu/TiO2 catalysts gradually shifted to the low temperature region, suggesting that the strong interaction between Cu and Sm species facilitates the blue shift of the Cu species reduction peak, which favors the reaction. The H2 consumption values of the catalysts are presented in Table 2. The Cu/TiO2 catalyst exhibits an H2 consumption of 246.45 μmol·g−1. With the addition of Sm species, the H2 consumption shows an increasing trend, reaching its highest value (362.88 μmol·g−1) at x = 4. However, it should be noted that the Cu content in the catalyst remains constant throughout the experiments. Hence, it can be reasonably inferred that the H2 consumption of the prepared catalysts should be equal or similar. The consumption of 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst H2 was 116.43 μmol·g−1 higher than that of Cu/TiO2 catalyst H2, which was inconsistent with the expected result. Combining the findings from XRD, Raman spectroscopy, and the activity curves, it can be inferred that doping Sm species induces lattice distortion in the TiO2 support. On the other hand, the doping of Sm species allows for more active substances to be loaded onto the distorted lattice, resulting in an increased H2 consumption trend. However, it does not imply that a higher doping concentration of Sm species leads to a greater amount of loaded active substances. Comparing the 10SmCu/TiO2 catalyst with the Cu/TiO2 catalyst, although the selectivity of N2 was improved by the 10SmCu/TiO2 catalyst, the catalytic activity and N2 yield of the 10SmCu/TiO2 catalyst were significantly lower than that of the Cu/TiO2 catalyst. On TiO2 support, excess Sm may compete with Cu, resulting in a decrease in active substances and thus a decrease in catalytic activity. 3.2.3 TEM and SEM study Fig. 4 shows TEM and SEM images of 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst. In Fig. 4(a), a low-resolution TEM image is presented, which clearly shows the 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst with a uniform particle size distribution. The particle sizes range from 4 to 12 nm, with an average particle size of 8.49 nm. In the high-resolution TEM image shown in Fig. 4(b), a periodic fringe (0.26 nm) can be observed, corresponding to the expected distance between the (200) grid planes of the anatase type TiO2. This indicates that the addition of Sm and Cu species does not alter the anatase structure of TiO2, which is consistent with the XRD results. Additionally, SEM images (c-f) reveal that the morphology of the 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst consists of stacked nanoparticles, confirming the TEM results. In order to further explore the composition distribution of the catalyst, element mapping was carried out, as shown in Fig. 5. From the figure, it is evident that Cu and Sm are uniformly dispersed on the entire surface of the catalyst. 3.3 Identification of active sites 3.3.1 Redox properties Fig. 6 shows the XPS spectra of Ti 2p, Cu 2p, Sm 3d and O1s on the Cu/TiO2 catalyst, 4Sm/TiO2 catalyst and xSmCu/TiO2 catalysts. Fig. 6(a) displays the Ti 2p XPS spectra of the Cu/TiO2 catalyst 4Sm/TiO2 catalyst and the xSmCu/TiO2 catalysts. The binding energies of all catalysts were ∼463.7 eV and ∼457.9 eV, respectively. The binding energy of the Ti4+ ions remained unchanged with the introduction of Sm species, indicating that no electron transfer happened on the TiO2 support. Fig. 6(b) shows the Cu 2p XPS spectra of Cu/TiO2 catalyst and xSmCu/TiO2 catalysts. All catalysts have two satellite peaks at ∼9365- ∼947.0 eV and ∼958.5- ∼964.0 eV. The characteristic peaks at ∼934.0 eV and ∼954.0 eV are Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 [43,44]. The XPS spectra of all catalysts Cu 2p can be deconvolved to 8 peaks corresponding to 4 pairs of spin orbital bespeaks [45]. It is worth noting that the binding energy of Cu2+ and Cu+ of Cu 2p3/2 is about at ∼934.2 eV and ∼933.0 eV when Cu/TiO2 catalyst are not doped with Sm species. After doping with Sm species, the Cu 2p3/2 peak of xSmCu/TiO2 catalysts shifts towards the direction of low binding energy. This is due to differences in electronegativity between metallic species, resulting in some electrons moving from Sm to the more electronegative Cu (Cu2++Sm2+⇌Cu++Sm3+)[46]. This suggests that doping Sm species can promote the formation of Cu+ species, and there is a synergistic effect between Cu+ and Cu2+, which can accelerate the redox cycle in the NH3-SCO process. As shown in Table 3, the Cu+ content reaches the highest in 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst, thus the synergistic effect between Cu+ and Cu2+ is further improved [47,48]. Fig. 6(c) shows the Sm 3d XPS spectra of 4Sm/TiO2 catalyst and xSmCu/TiO2 catalysts. All peaks with a binding energy of ∼1082.7 eV can be deconvolved into two peaks representing Sm3+ and Sm2+ [46]. By comparing the 4Sm/TiO2 catalyst, it is evident that the Sm3+ and Sm2+ species in the xSmCu/TiO2 catalysts have shifted to higher binding energy positions, confirming the occurrence of electron transfer between Cu and Sm. Table 3 indicates that when x = 4, the Sm3+ content reaches its maximum, further supporting the presence of electron transfer between Cu and Sm species. Fig. 6(d) shows the O 1 s XPS spectra of Cu/TiO2 catalyst, 4Sm/TiO2 catalyst and xSmCu/TiO2 catalysts. Here, Oα refers to surface-adsorbed oxygen, while Oβ refers to lattice oxygen [1,49]. According to relevant reports, surface-adsorbed oxygen is more active than lattice oxygen in oxidation reactions, mainly because the mobility of Oα is higher than Oβ. Compared with Cu/TiO2 catalyst, Oα content increased with doping of Sm species [39]. The results show that when x = 4, that is, 4SmCu/TiO2, the Oα content reaches the highest, up to 24.0% which is 1.5 times of the Oα content of Cu/TiO2 catalyst (16.0%). The results showed that the number of Oα species increased greatly after the introduction of Sm species, which was conducive to improving the catalytic performance of NH3-SCO. 3.3.2 O2 temperature programmed desorption The O2-TPD results of the Cu/TiO2 catalyst and xSmCu/TiO2 catalysts are shown in Fig. 7. O2-TPD can detect three O2 desorption peaks, where α desorption peak is the surface-adsorbed oxygen, β peak is the surface lattice oxygen desorption peak, and γ desorption peak is the reduction peak of internal lattice oxygen [50,51]. As can be seen from Fig. 7, the peak area of γ desorption peaks on all xSmCu/TiO2 catalysts sharply decreased after the doping of Sm. After doping Sm species, the reduction peak of internal lattice oxygen is transformed into surface-adsorbed oxygen and lattice oxygen, which enhances the catalytic activity of xSmCu/TiO2 catalysts. Combined with XPS result analysis, it is shown that there is a strong interaction between Sm and Cu, which can effectively increase the surface adsorption oxygen content of xSmCu/TiO2 catalysts, thereby greatly improving the catalytic performance of xSmCu/TiO2 catalysts. 3.3.3 Identification of Lewis acid sites and Brønsted acid sites The acidity of catalyst is an important index to evaluate the catalytic performance of solid catalysts. In Fig. 8(a) and (b), the acid sites of Cu/TiO2 catalyst and 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst were determined by FTIR spectra of pyridine desorption at different temperatures. The graphs show the acid sites located at 1444 cm−1, 1490 cm−1, 1541 cm−1 (1550 cm−1), 1576 cm−1, 1595 cm−1, 1576 cm−1, 1595 cm−1, and 1611 cm−1. Among them, the adsorption bands at 1444 cm−1 and 1595 cm−1 were correlated with Lewis acid sites (LASs), the adsorption band at 1541 cm−1 (1550 cm−1) was correlated with Brønsted acid sites (BASs), and the adsorption bands at 1490 cm−1and the energy bands around 1575 cm−1 are associated with both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites [52,53]. As can be seen from Table 4, the Lewis content of both catalysts is significantly higher than the Brønsted content, which implies that the Lewis content is relatively high in both catalysts. Meanwhile, the intensity of Lewis and Brønsted adsorption bands gradually decreased with increasing temperature, which could be attributed to the dissociation of adsorbed species on the catalyst surface with increasing temperature, which led to a decrease in the intensity of adsorption bands. In addition, from the relative intensities of the spectra at 150 °C, the 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst adsorbed more pyridine compared to the Cu/TiO2 catalyst, which suggests that the introduction of Sm species can increase the acidity of the catalyst. In summary, the Cu/TiO2 catalyst and the 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst have acidic sites, with the Lewis acidic sites having higher intensities and the 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst having stronger acidity [53]. These results provide important indicators for assessing the acidity and catalytic performance of the catalysts. Fig. 8(c). shows the Cu/TiO2 catalyst and xSmCu/TiO2 catalysts NH3-TPD spectra. NH3-TPD can be used to evaluate the surface acidity and NH3 adsorption capacity of the catalyst. The temperature of NH3-TPD can be divided into two zones. When the temperature is lower than 200 ℃, it mainly involves NH3 desorption at Lewis acid sites, while when the temperature is higher than 350 ℃, it mainly involves NH3 desorption at Brønsted acid sites [54,55]. As shown in Fig. 8(c), the α peak corresponds to physical desorption peaks, which occurs at the weak Lewis acid site. The β peak corresponds the desorption peaks of NH3 adsorbed on the strong Lewis acid site. γ peak corresponds NH3 adsorbed on Brønsted acid site for desorption peaks. At the weak Lewis acid site, with increasing Sm doping, the desorption peak of the xSmCu/TiO2 catalysts at the weak Lewis acid site (α peak) gradually increases and shifts to the strong Lewis acid site, with the most significant change observed at 4SmCu/TiO2. This trend indicates that the number of Lewis acid sites gradually increases, significantly enhancing the number of active sites on the catalyst surface. Consistent with the results of pyridine infrared. The Cu2+ adsorption activity on the catalyst surface is indicated by the β peak. The figure shows that the β peak gradually transforms into the α peak upon Sm doping, with the transition being most evident at 4SmCu/TiO2. This suggests that Sm doping lowers the temperature at which Cu2+ adsorbs [56]. Thus, the catalytic performance of the catalyst is improved. 3.3.4 Evolution of catalyst species Fig. 9(a) and (b) show the continuous 30 min absorption of Cu/TiO2 and 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst in NH3 at 50 °C, respectively. Fig. 9(a) demonstrates that the depletion of surface hydroxyl groups results in negative bands at 3660 cm−1 and 3636 cm−1 [60,61]. while the N-H stretching vibration of the coordination NH3 is responsible for the adsorption bands at 3394 cm−1,3330 cm−1,3253 cm−1,3208 cm−1 and 3141 cm−1 [57–59]. In the NH3-SCO reaction process, the adsorption capacity of NH3 is typically measured by the presence of acid sites on the catalyst surface, namely Brønsted acid sites (such as hydroxyl) and Lewis acid sites (unsaturated metal coordination) [9,60]. The adsorption bands at 1616 cm−1 and 1226 cm−1 were attributed to Lewis acid site (NH3L) [57,59], while those at 1397 cm−1 were attributed to Brønsted acid site (NH4 +B) [47,60,61]. Observing Fig. 9(a), it can be noted that N-H stretching vibrations were not detected during the first 2 min when the Cu/TiO2 catalyst was involved. However, as the adsorption time increased, these vibrations gradually appeared. Conversely, Fig. 9(b) clearly indicates the presence of N-H stretching vibrations when the 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst participates in the reaction, and these vibrations intensify over time. Notably, at low temperatures, the adsorption performance of the Cu/TiO2 catalyst is inferior to that of the 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst. Furthermore, the Lewis adsorption band at 1230 cm−1 exhibits significantly higher intensity compared to that of the Cu/TiO2 catalyst, suggesting that the 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst possesses abundant acid sites, thus enhancing NH3 adsorption performance. Fig. 9(c) and (d) show the surface reaction of Cu/TiO2 catalyst and 4SmCu/ TiO2 catalyst with NH3 at different temperatures ranging from 50 to 300 ℃, respectively. Fig. 9(c) shows that N-H stretching vibrations are not detected at 50 °C and 100 °C. When combined with Fig. 9(a), this indicates that the Cu/TiO2 catalyst surface lacks the ability to rapidly adsorb NH3 at these temperatures. In Fig. 9(d), it is evident that significant N-H stretching vibrations occur across the temperature range of 50–300 °C, and the intensity of the adsorption band is notably enhanced compared to that of the Cu/TiO2 catalyst. Additionally, the adsorption band of the Lewis acid site at 1612 cm−1 and 1224 cm−1 demonstrates a decrease in NH3 adsorption strength with increasing temperature, while the Brønsted acid site remains unaffected by temperature variations. This suggests that, in the NH3-SCO reaction, Lewis acid sites play a dominant role. Moreover, the adsorption band of the 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst exhibits overall stronger intensity throughout the spectrum compared to the Cu/TiO2 catalyst. This indicates that the catalyst possesses stronger acidity and more coordination unsaturated Cu species for NH3 adsorption, allowing NH3 to be adsorbed on the catalyst surface in the form of stable intermediates. Consequently, non-selective oxidation of NH3 and O2 during the NH3-SCO reaction process is reduced. Fig. 9(e) and (f) show the surface reaction of NH3 +O2 with temperature on Cu/TiO2 and 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst at different temperatures ranging from 50 ℃ to 300 ℃. In Fig. 9(e), the adsorption band of amide (-NH2) was observed only at 1646 cm−1 [62,63]. Meanwhile, the adsorption bands at 1515 cm−1 and 1288 cm−1 represent the two-tooth nitrate band and single-tooth nitrate band, and is the result of adsorption of intermediate species NOx produced by NH3 in catalytic oxidation [64,65]. As can be seen form Fig. 9(f), the adsorption band at 1646 cm−1 and 1159 cm−1 represents the oscillating vibration of amide (-NH2) [32]. With the increase of temperature, the strength of the adsorption band began to weaken, and the adsorption band at 1159 cm−1 shifts blue to 1189 cm−1. The blue shift phenomenon may be caused by the interaction between the surrounding environment and hydrogen bond with the increase of temperature, which changes the vibration frequency of hydrogen bond. As can be seen from Fig. 9(e) and (f), the peak value of adsorption band of 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst at 1646 cm−1 and 1159 cm−1 is much higher than that of Cu/TiO2 catalyst, indicating abundant amide (-NH2) on the surface. Fig. 9(g) and (h) show the reaction of O2 with NH3 pre-adsorbed on the surface of Cu/TiO2 and 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst at 250 ℃. As can be seen from Fig. 9(g), the negative bands at 3360 cm−1,3636 cm−1 disappeared and disappeared, while the adsorption bands at 3392 cm−1, 3360 cm−1, 3262 cm−1, 3320 cm−1, and 3157 cm−1 showed a tendency of weakening, suggesting that some of the NH3 was desorbed on the surface of the catalyst with the entry of O2. A weak amide (-NH2) adsorption band was also observed at 1646 cm−1, and the adsorption bands of monodentate nitrate and bidentate nitrate were observed at 1288 cm−1 and 1515 cm−1, respectively. The adsorption bands at 3393 cm−1, 3360 cm−1, 3266 cm−1, 3211 cm−1 and 3155 cm−1 also showed a weakening trend as shown in Fig. 9(h). The adsorption bands of Lewis acid site and Brønsted acid site were still clearly observed at 1608 cm−1 and 1397 cm−1. Meanwhile, the monodentate nitrate at 1288 cm−1 and the bidentate nitrate zone at 1516 cm−1 were more stable. the amide (-NH2) adsorption bands at 1186 cm−1 and 1646 cm−1 were also able to stabilise. In summary, the introduction of O2 led to the reduction of amide(-NH2) intermediates of Cu/TiO2 catalyst, while it had no effect on the amide(-NH2) intermediates of 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst. 3.4 Proposed NH3-SCO reaction mechanism and kinetic analysis To summarize, both Cu/TiO2 catalysts and 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst exhibit the formation of nitrate bands during the NH3-SCO reaction, which aligns with the "internal" selective catalytic reduction (iSCR) mechanism. Fig. 10 illustrates the reaction mechanism of the 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst. One crucial intermediate in the NH3-SCO reaction is amide (-NH2), which can reduce generated (-NO) to N2 and water vapor. From Fig. 9(e) and (f), it is evident that the 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst generates a significant amount of amide (-NH2) during the reaction, while the Cu/TiO2 catalyst largely converts the amide (-NH2) into (-NO), leading to the production of numerous by-products. As a result, the selective oxidation of NH3 and O2 is greatly diminished. Overall, the iSCR mechanism involving the amide (-NH2) intermediate has proven effective in reducing NOx emissions during the NH3-SCO reaction. The reaction pathway of the 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst in the NH3-SCO process is as follows: NH3 initially reacts with reactive oxygen species to form (-NH2) (Eq. (12)). Subsequently, this amide undergoes dehydrogenation with reactive oxygen species, step by step, to form NO (Eqs. (13)–(15)). Finally, the amide (-NH2) reacts with NO to yield N2 and water (Eq. (16)). (10) O 2 → O 2 ads (11) O 2 ads → 2 O (12) NH 3 + O → − NH 2 + OH ads (13) − NH 2 + O → − NH + OH ads (14) − NH + O → − N + OH ads (15) − N + O → − NO (16) − NH 2 + − NO → N 2 + H 2 O (17) OH ads + OH ads → H 2 O + O Fig. 11. shows the oxidation kinetics of NH3 over Cu/TiO2 catalyst and 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst. The experimental details can be found in the support information. In order to investigate the influence of external diffusion on the reaction rate of the catalyst, the catalytic activity of different amounts of catalysts at the space velocity 60,000⋅h−1 was measured, as shown in Fig. S6. Cu/TiO2-1 catalyst, 4SmCu/TiO2-1 catalyst, Cu/TiO2-2 catalyst, 4SmCu/TiO2-2 catalyst and Cu/TiO2-3 catalyst, 4SmCu/TiO2-3 catalyst represent the conversion of NH3 at 250 ppm,500 ppm and 750 ppm. The results show that the catalytic performance of Cu/TiO2 catalyst and 4SmCu/TiO2 catalysts is in good agreement, indicating that external diffusion has little effect on the reaction rate. Fig. 11 also shows that the apparent activation energies of 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst and Cu/TiO2 catalyst are 22.06 kJ mol−1 and 32.26 kJ mol−1, respectively. This suggests that the 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst has a lower reaction energy barrier than the Cu/TiO2 catalyst, which is a contributing factor to its higher catalytic activity. 4 Conclusion This paper describes the preparation of a highly N2 selective catalyst using TiO2 as a support, Cu as the active species, and Sm as an auxiliary agent. The selective catalytic performance of the catalyst was investigated, and the results show that when NH3 conversion reached 100%, the introduction of Sm can completely convert NH3 into harmless N2 and water vapor. The active species were found to be highly dispersed on the support through a series of characterizations. Additionally, the surface of the 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst exhibits abundant Lewis acid sites and surface-adsorbed oxygen, which promotes the adsorption and transformation of NH3 molecules. The study of the reaction mechanism reveals that the 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst follows the "internal" selective catalytic reduction (iSCR) mechanism during NH3-SCO reaction. Abundant Lewis acid sites and amides (-NH2) are generated during the reaction, significantly reducing the non-selective oxidation of NH3 and O2, thereby improving the selectivity for N2. Moreover, kinetic studies demonstrate that the 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst reduces the apparent activation energy compared to the Cu/TiO2 catalyst, indicating a lower reaction energy barrier when reacting on the 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst, effectively promoting the reaction. In summary, these findings suggest that the 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst is a promising material with superior catalytic activity and selectivity for NH3-SCO. coredata.dc:description: The selective catalytic oxidation of ammonia (NH3-SCO) is currently the most effective method used to eliminate NH3. However, one of the major challenges for NH3-SCO is the development of catalyst capable of completely converting NH3 into harmless N2 and water vapor. In this paper, a high N2 selective catalyst prepared by the sol-gel method using TiO2 as the support, Cu as the active species, and Sm as the auxiliary agent is presented. Compared to traditional Cu/TiO2 catalyst, the 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst has higher catalytic activity and N2 selectivity at low temperatures. The NH3 conversion can reach 100%, and the selectivity of N2 can be maintained at 100% at 275 °C. The excellent catalytic activity is attributed to the highly dispersed active species, abundant Lewis acid sites (LASs), and the generation of large amounts of surface-adsorbed oxygen. In addition, doping Sm species will cause TiO2 lattice distortion, and at the same time load the distorted TiO2 with more active material. Moreover, in-situ DRIFTS analysis suggests that both the 4SmCu/TiO2 and Cu/TiO2 catalysts follow the "internal" selective catalytic reduction (iSCR) mechanism during NH3-SCO reactions. The 4SmCu/TiO2 catalyst generates more amides (-NH2), which reduces the non-selective oxidation of the catalysts and promotes the formation of N2. This provides a new idea and method for the selective catalytic oxidation of NH3 to N2 and water vapor using Cu-based catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Reasonable design of Sm-modified Cu-based catalyst for NH3-SCO: Role of the amide intermediates
